places.name: Ager River
places.description: The Ager River in Austria is a tributary of the Traun.

places.name: Mondsee
places.description: Mondsee is a town in Upper Austria located on the shore of the lake, Mondsee.

places.name: Kammersee
places.description: The Kammersee, or Attersee, is a lake in Upper Austria.

places.name: Unterach am Attersee
places.description: Unterach is a village in the Austria state of Upper Austria on the southern shore of lake Attersee in the centre of the Salzkammergut region.

places.description: Town on the Vöckla river, between Vöcklabruck and Frankenmarkt

places.name: Salzburg
places.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

places.name: Bad Aussee
places.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

places.name: Gorizia
places.description: Gorizia is a town and comune in north-eastern Italy, in the autonomous region of Friuli Venezia Giulia.

places.name: Vienna
places.description: Austria’s capital, lies in the country’s east on the Danube River.

places.name: Salzburg
places.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

places.name: Traunstein
places.description: Traunstein is a town in the south-eastern part of Bavaria, Germany, and is the administrative center of a much larger district of the same name.

places.name: Traun
places.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

places.name: Traun
places.description: The Traun is a river in Upper Bavaria, Germany. The nearly 29 kilometer long river is formed by the confluence of the Weiße Traun and the Rote Traun near Siegsdorf. It passes through Traunstein and Traunreut, and flows into the Alz near Altenmarkt an der Alz.

places.name: Traun
places.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

places.name: Traun
places.description: The Traun is a river in Upper Bavaria, Germany. The nearly 29 kilometer long river is formed by the confluence of the Weiße Traun and the Rote Traun near Siegsdorf. It passes through Traunstein and Traunreut, and flows into the Alz near Altenmarkt an der Alz.

places.name: Traunstein
places.description: Traunstein is a town in the south-eastern part of Bavaria, Germany, and is the administrative center of a much larger district of the same name.

places.name: Chiemsee
places.description: picturesque lake in Bavaria

places.name: Bad Aibling
places.description: Bad Aibling is a spa town and former district seat in Bavaria on the river Mangfall, located some 56 km southeast of Munich.

places.name: Munich
places.description: the capital of Bavaria in Germany

persons.name: Marcus ElieserBloch
persons.description: German physician and naturalist who specialised in the study of fish on which he published a 12 volume work with which Davy was familiar. (presumably in the French translation).

persons.name: Johann AndreasWagner
persons.description: a German palaeontologist, zoologist and archaeologist who wrote several important works on palaeontology.

places.name: Munich
places.description: the capital of Bavaria in Germany

places.name: River Danube
places.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

places.name: Ljubljana

places.name: Starnberg

places.name: Bregenz

places.name: Tyrol
places.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

places.name: Füssen

places.name: Appenzell
places.description: a canton in the northeast of Switzerland, the southern part of which is mountainous

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

persons.name: George GordonByron
persons.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

places.name: Wandle
places.description: A tributary of the River Thames in south London, England. Davy writes a poem 'To the Wandle, or Vandalis' (notebook 14E, pp. 122-1) and writes about the river in Samonia.

places.name: Sava River
places.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

places.name: Mount's Bay

persons.name: JosephineDetela
persons.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

places.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

persons.name: Cain

persons.name: Julian
persons.description: Julian was the Caesar of the West from 355 to 360 and Roman emperor from 361 to 363, as well as a notable philosopher and author in Greek. His rejection of Christianity, and his promotion of Neoplatonic Hellenism in its place, caused him to be remembered as Julian the Apostate in Christian tradition.

persons.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
persons.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

persons.name: George GordonByron
persons.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

persons.name: Constantine
persons.description: Roman emperor from AD 306 to 337; he patronised Christianity and was converted to it on his deathbed.

persons.name: JohnMilton
persons.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

persons.name: WilliamShakespeare
persons.description: English playwright and poet.

persons.name: Jupiter
persons.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

places.name: London

places.name: Tahiti
places.description: Tahiti is the largest island in French Polynesia, the South Pacific archipelago. Shaped like a figure-8, it's divided into Tahiti Nui (the larger, western section) and Tahiti Iti (the eastern peninsula). It was known as Otaheite in the time Davy was writing.
